docs.title: Base de datos
docs.text:
Una tabla en MySQL es una estructura dentro de una base de datos que organiza los datos en filas y columnas, como si fuera una hoja de cálculo.

Cada fila (row) representa un registro individual, y cada columna (column) representa un campo de dato

Ejemplo: Una tabla alumnos podría tener columnas como id, nombre, edad, correo, etc., y cada fila representa un alumno distinto.

docs.title: Ejemplo de tabla en SQL
docs.text: ```sql title="Crear tabla alumnos" CREATE TABLE alumnos ( id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, nombre VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL, edad INT, correo VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE );

docs.title: ☠️ Threats and Vulnerabilities
docs.text:
Threat: harm, lost, damage or compromise info or system

Threat Descripción Natural Disasters Harm, damage Cyber-attacks harm, damage Data Integrity breaches harm, damage Disclosure of confidential information harm. damage

Vulnerability: Any weakness in the system design or implementation They come from internal factors

  • Software bugs
  • Misconfigured software
  • Improperly protected network devices
  • Missing security patches
  • Lack of physical security

but it can be prevent from being exploited

  • Mitigating
  • Transferring, avoiding or accepting the risk (becomes a risk management decision)

Remember Neme: If I have:

  • Threat + No vulnerability = No Risk
  • Vulnerability + No threat = No Risk

Risk Management: Finding different ways to minimize the likelihood (probabilitie) of an outcome occurring and achieve the desired outcomes.

Cybersecurity is the continuity of services to the end users, maintaining the overall security of the systems and protect the organization from data breaches by minimizing the vulnerabilities or mitigating the risk it this impact.

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text:
Protect the information from unauthorized access and disclosure (Could be an individual, entity or process).

Keeping information secret and safe from prying eyes, only access who they need to access.

3 main reasons of Confidentiality

  1. Protect personal privacy
  2. Maintain a business advantage
  3. Achieve regulatory compliance (PII, PHI, Various types of financial data
  4. PII: Personal identifiable information, PHI: Protected health info.

How to maintain the Confidentiality

  1. Encryption
  2. Access Controls
  3. Data Masking
  4. Physical Security Measures
  5. Training and awareness

docs.title: 🔐 Integrity Overview
docs.text: Protects data from unauthorized changes to maintain accuracy.

docs.title: ✅ Methods to Maintain Integrity
docs.text: Method Details Example 🔢 Hashing Converts data into a fixed-size value to detect unauthorized changes. Comparing hash values before and after file transfer. ✍️ Digital Signatures Ensure both the integrity and authenticity of data. Signing a PDF to confirm authorship and prevent tampering. ✔️ Checksums Used to verify data integrity during transmission. Verifying downloaded software with provided checksum value. 🔐 Access Controls Only authorized users can modify data, reducing risks of tampering. Only HR can update employee salary records. 📋 Regular Audits Systematically review logs and changes; identify unauthorized modifications quickly. Reviewing system logs weekly to detect unauthorized changes.

docs.title: 📶 Availability Overview
docs.text:
Ensures that information, systems, and resources are accessible and operational when needed by authorized users. | Employees can access internal systems 24/7 without downtime. |

🔎 Why Availability Matters

Benefit Description Example Business Continuity Keeps operations running during failures A backup server activates instantly after the main one fails. Customer Trust Maintains reliable services Users trust online banking due to constant service uptime. Organization's Reputation Avoids negative impact due to outages A retail site remains online during high-traffic holiday sales.

🔁 Redundancy Strategies:

To overcome the challenges associated with maintaining availability, the best strategy is to use redundancy in the systems and network designs.

Redundancy Type Description Example **Redundancy ** Duplication of critical components or functions to enhance reliability. Having a backup internet connection and server for critical services. Server Redundancy Uses multiple servers in a load-balanced or failover configuration to maintain service availability. If one server crashes, others continue handling user traffic. Data Redundancy Stores data in multiple locations to prevent loss or access failure. Cloud storage syncing data across different regions. Network Redundancy Uses multiple network paths to ensure data delivery if one route fails. Internet reroutes through a backup ISP line if the main one is down. Power Redundancy Uses backup power sources like UPS or generators to avoid power-related downtime. Data center switches to generator during a city-wide blackout.

docs.title: 🔏 Non-repudiation
docs.text: Aspect Description Definition Ensures undeniable proof that participants cannot deny their involvement in digital actions. Importance - Confirms authenticity of digital transactions- Ensures integrity of communications- Provides accountability in digital processes

docs.title: ✍️ Digital Signatures
docs.text:
Aspect Description Definition Unique to each user; created by hashing a message and encrypting it with the user's private key using asymmetric encryption. Purpose Verify authenticity and integrity of digital communications.

○ Importance of Non-repudiation: - ✔️ To confirm the authenticity of digital transactions - ✔️ To ensure the integrity of critical communications - ✔️ To provide accountability in digital processes

docs.title: 🔐Authentication
docs.text:
Verifies the identity of individuals or entities in a communication or transaction

🔐 5 Authentication Methods Overview

Authentication Method Description Example Authentication (General) Ensures individuals or entities are who they claim to be during a communication or transaction. Logging into a secure website with a password. Something You Know (Knowledge) Relies on information that a user can recall. Passwords, PINs, or security questions. Something You Have (Possession) Relies on presenting a physical item to authenticate. Security token, smart card, or a mobile authenticator app. Something You Are (Inherence) Uses unique physical or behavioral traits of a person. Fingerprint, face scan, or retina scan. Something You Do (Action) Depends on a user’s unique behavior or action. Typing rhythm, voice recognition. Somewhere You Are (Location) Uses the user's geographic location as a factor in authentication. Logging in only when located at the office or within a country.

○ Authentication is critical to understand because of the following:

  • ✅ To prevent unauthorized access
  • 🔒 To protect user data and privacy
  • 👤 To ensure that resources are accessed by valid users only

docs.title: 🔑 Authorization
docs.text:
○ Authorization Pertains to the permissions and privileges granted to users or entities after they have been authenticated.

○ Authorization mechanisms are important to help us with the following: - 🔒 To protect sensitive data - 🛡️ To maintain the system integrity in our organizations - ⚙️ To create a more streamlined user experience

docs.title: 📊 Accounting
docs.text:
Tracks and records all user activities during communication or transactions.

✅ The organization should use a robust accounting system creating the following process:

Topic Description Example Audit Trail Chronological record to trace changes or unauthorized access. Reviewing logs after a security breach. Regulatory Compliance Maintains records to meet legal and industry standards. Providing logs during a compliance audit. Forensic Analysis Helps understand incidents to prevent recurrence. Analyzing event logs after a cyberattack. Resource Optimization Tracks usage to improve system performance and cost-efficiency. Monitoring bandwidth to reduce overuse. User Accountability Ensures user actions are logged to deter misuse. Tracking employee activity on critical systems. Technology Purpose Example Syslog Servers Aggregate logs from devices for analysis. Central log server collecting firewall logs. Network Analysis Tools Capture and analyze network traffic. Monitoring suspicious traffic on a corporate LAN. SIEM Systems Real-time security alert analysis. Detecting unusual login attempts immediately.

docs.title: 🔒 Security Controls Categories
docs.text:
Multifaceted layers of protection to form a security posture

Main function to protect Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability

Categories Descripción Technical Controls HW and SW implemented to manage and reduce risk (Firewalls, Encryption, Intrusion Detection Systems) Managerial Controls or Administrative Controls Strategic planning and governance side of security align to the business goal and risk tolerance (conduct a risk assessments, security policies, training programs, incident response strategies for make decision and keep informed the organization in the same security page) Operational Controls Procedures and measures designed to protect data on a day to day basis most of them governed by internal processes and human actions (change the passwd, backup procedures, account reviews, user training programs). this can be ongoing process to ensure the security. Physical Controls Tangible, real-world measures taken to protect assets: digital and non-digital. (Shredding of sensitive documents, Security guards, Locking doors).

docs.title: 🛡️ Security Control Types
docs.text:
This will depend of the specific threat o vulnerability to address

Types Objective Description Preventive Controls proactive measures, build foundation proactive measures implemented to thwart potential security threats or breaches before the inciden occur (firewall). Deterrent Controls discourage threats- warnings Aim to discourage potential attackers by making the effort seem less appealing or more challenging. **( Warning Signs, banners to indicate the monitoring is occurring) Detective Controls detection and notification, watchful eye Monitor and alert to malicious activities as the occur or shortly thereafter. ** (Network: IDS (Intrusion-Detection-System).** Corrective Controls jumping in emergencies Mitigate any potential damage and restore the system to their normal state.*(mitigate the vulnerabilities). Compensating Controls backups and mitigations Alternative measure implemented when primary security controls are not feasible or effective (plan b of security)example: in a test online: 3 layers of security network: my phone, cable dsl, wifi)** Directive Controls guide the entire process Policy or documentation that set the standards for behavior in the organization. (policy how employs use company-owned IT assets).

docs.title: 🔐 Zero Trust:  Never trust, always verify...
docs.text:
This mean we can not just trust to the network perimeter to protect the system as a main line of defense, with deperimeterization (common in cloud and remote work and adoption of new technologies)we are put a lot or risk into the organization that is why we need to focus on: strong authentication, data encryption access controls per user/devices, zero trust architecture.

Zero Trust demands verify for every device, user and transaction within the network, regardless of its origin (it doesn't mater where it comes from: inside or outside the network.

Types Objective Description Control Plane is the brain (making decisions) Adaptive Identity, threat scope reduction, policy-driven access control, secured zones with Policy Engine and Policy Administrator. Data Plane is the hands (doing the work) Subject/System and Policy Enforcement Point

📌 Control Plane

Control Plane Description Control Plane responsible for defining, managing, and enforcing the policies related to user and system access. Adaptive Identity validation into account user behavior, device, location and more. Threat scope reduction Limit he access only for the need work tasks, avoid risk and compromise credentials. Policy-driven access control Enforce user access policies based on their roles and responsibilities. Secured zones Isolated environments within a network that are designed to house sensitive data.

Control Plane uses: Policy Engine and Policy Administrator to makes security decisions.

Decision-making and enforcement What it does How it works Example Question? Policy Engine Makes decisions based on policies Evaluates context like user identity, device health, location, and request type. Decides if a user with a healthy laptop and MFA can access a sensitive app. Should this request be allowed? Policy Administrator Enforces the decision from the Policy Engine. Connects to the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) to allow or block traffic. Sends an “allow” command to the firewall or gateway to permit access. Apply the Policy Engine’s decision

The Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) is the security gateway or system that executes the decision: allow, block, or limit user/device access.

🔁 Flow Summary: 1. User makes a request. 2. Policy Engine evaluates based on policies 3. Policy Administrator applies the decision via the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP).

📌 Data Plane

Component What it Does How it Works Example Subject/System Verify the authenticity of the subject or system. The user, device, or application requesting access to resources. Sends access requests and presents credentials or context to the system. An employee’s laptop trying to access a corporate app. Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) Enforces access control decisions by allowing or blocking data flow. Acts as a gateway or proxy that checks with the Control Plane before permitting access. Firewall, secure proxy, or cloud access gateway controlling traffic to an app.

docs.title: ⚠️ Gap Analysis
docs.text:
Is the process used to compare the current state of a process, system, or performance against a desired future state. It helps identify the "gaps" or differences that need to be addressed to achieve the goals.

Example: A company wants to improve its cybersecurity posture. The current state shows basic firewall protection, but the desired state includes advanced threat detection and response capabilities. The gap analysis reveals missing tools and processes that must be implemented to reach the desired security level.

Current State Desired State Identified Gap Basic firewall protection Advanced threat detection & response Lack of security monitoring tools Manual patch management Automated patch deployment Need for automation in updates Limited employee training Regular security awareness training Insufficient user education

docs.title: 🔍 Scanning and Tools
docs.text: Tool/Term Short Definition Example Vulnerability Management The ongoing process of identifying, assessing, prioritizing, and remediating security weaknesses. Regularly scanning systems to find and fix software bugs. CVE Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures; unique ID for vulnerabilities. CVE-2023-12345 identifying a specific software flaw. CVSS Common Vulnerability Scoring System; rates severity of vulnerabilities. CVSS score 9.8 indicating a critical vulnerability. CWE Common Weakness Enumeration; categorizes types of software weaknesses. CWE-79 refers to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS). OWASP Open Web Application Security Project; provides web app security guidelines. OWASP Top 10 listing critical web security risks.

docs.title: 🔄 Change Management
docs.text: Term Short Definition Example Change Any addition, modification, or removal of anything that could affect IT services. Upgrading the company’s email server software. Problem Underlying cause of one or more incidents affecting services. Repeated server crashes traced back to faulty software. Incident Unplanned interruption or reduction in quality of an IT service. Network outage causing loss of connectivity for users. Emergency Change Management Fast-tracked change process to address critical issues urgently. Patching a critical security vulnerability immediately. RCA (Root Cause Analysis) Process to identify the fundamental cause of a problem or incident. Investigating why a database failure occurred and fixing it.

docs.title: 🌅 Sunset Process
docs.text: Term Short Definition Example Offboarding App Process of decommissioning an application from active use. Retiring an old HR system and migrating users to a new one. Remove Data Securely deleting all data related to the decommissioned app. Wiping user records and logs from the old app database. Remove Infra Shutting down and dismantling infrastructure supporting the app. Deleting virtual servers and storage used by the retired app.

docs.text: Component Description Example BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) Legacy firmware that initializes hardware and starts the bootloader Accessed by pressing F2 or Del during startup UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) Modern firmware replacing BIOS, with more features and faster booting Accessed via F12 or Esc on newer systems mkinitrd Creates an initial RAM disk image for booting mkinitrd /boot/initrd.img-$(uname -r) grub2-install Installs the GRUB2 bootloader to a device grub2-install /dev/sda grub2-mkconfig Generates a new GRUB2 configuration file grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg grub2-update Updates GRUB2 with the latest kernel (alias for grub2-mkconfig on some systems) grub2-update dracut Tool to generate initramfs (initial RAM filesystem) dracut -f initrd.img Initial RAM disk used during early boot /boot/initrd.img-5.15.0 vmlinuz Compressed Linux kernel executable /boot/vmlinuz-5.15.0 GRUB2 (Grand Unified Bootloader v2) Bootloader that loads and transfers control to the Linux kernel /boot/grub2/grub.cfg PXE (Preboot Execution Environment) Boots system from a network server Booting diskless workstations using PXE server USB Boot Boots system from a USB flash drive Installing Linux from /dev/sdb1 ISO Boot Boots system from an ISO image Booting from ubuntu.iso using virtual machine or USB

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 Gestión de Usuarios
docs.text:
Comando Descripción sudo useradd nombre_usuario Crea un nuevo usuario. sudo useradd -m nombre_usuario Crea usuario y su directorio personal. sudo passwd nombre_usuario Asigna o cambia la contraseña del usuario. sudo userdel nombre_usuario Elimina un usuario (sin borrar su home). sudo userdel -r nombre_usuario Elimina usuario y su carpeta personal. sudo usermod -l nuevo_nombre antiguo_nombre Cambia el nombre de un usuario. sudo usermod -d /nueva/ruta nombre_usuario Cambia el directorio personal. sudo usermod -aG grupo nombre_usuario Añade usuario a un grupo sin quitar los anteriores. sudo usermod -L nombre_usuario Bloquea al usuario. sudo usermod -U nombre_usuario Desbloquea al usuario. sudo chage -l nombre_usuario info extendida el usuario, se necesita instalar 
    Ejemplo: Vpena:x:1001:1001:Viviana Pena /home/Vpena/bin/bash
    Vpena: nombre del usuario
    X: contraseña encriptada (etc/shadow)
    1001: UID
    1001: GID
    Viviana Pena: descripción
    /home/Vpena: carpeta personal
    /bin/bash: shell predeterminado

docs.title: 🔍 Consultar Información de Usuarios
docs.text: Comando Descripción id nombre_usuario Muestra UID, GID y grupos del usuario. groups nombre_usuario Muestra los grupos del usuario. getent passwd nombre_usuario Muestra entrada completa del usuario desde /etc/passwd. grep nombre /etc/passwd Busca información del usuario en el archivo passwd. chage -l nombre_usuario Muestra información sobre caducidad de contraseña. who Muestra quién está conectado. w Muestra quién está conectado y qué está haciendo. last Muestra historial de inicios de sesión. users Lista los usuarios conectados. su nombre_usuario Cambia al usuario especificado.

docs.title: 🔐 Permisos en Linux
docs.text: En Linux, los permisos determinan qué acciones puede realizar un usuario sobre un archivo o directorio.

docs.title: 📁 Tipos de Permisos
docs.text: Letra Nombre Descripción r read Leer el archivo o listar el directorio. w write Escribir/modificar el archivo o contenido del directorio. x execute Ejecutar un archivo o acceder a un directorio.

docs.title: 👥 Clases de Usuarios
docs.text: Letra Clase Descripción u user El dueño del archivo. g group El grupo asociado al archivo. o others Todos los demás usuarios. a all Todos (u + g + o).

docs.title: 🔍 Ver permisos con ls -l
docs.text:
ls -l archivo.txt

Ejemplo: -rw-r--r-- 1 juan staff  1024 may 30 12:00 archivo.txt
Descripción
- `-` → tipo de archivo (`-` = archivo regular, `d` = directorio)
- `rw-` → permisos del usuario (owner)
- `r--` → permisos del grupo
- `r--` → permisos para otros

docs.title: Mkdocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org. https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.
  • http://127.0.0.1:8000/database/

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
• mkdocs.yml The configuration file.
  • docs/index.md The documentation homepage.*
  • ... Other markdown pages, images and other files.
  • Note when the txt does not allow to save as .md save it : save as "file_name.md" (between double quote)

docs.title: Command  What it does
docs.text:
• mkdocs serve Preview docs live at http://127.0.0.1:8000/
  • mkdocs build Builds the updated site into the site/ folder
  • mkdocs gh-deploy Publishes your changes to GitHub Pages
  • Run on gitbash

docs.title: Workflow Summary
docs.text:
Edit your .md files in docs/

  • Update mkdocs.yml to reflect new pages
  • Run mkdocs serve to preview
  • Run git add ., git commit -m "...", git push
  • Deploy with mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: Desplegar en GitHub Pages
docs.text:
• checar el repositorio en GitHub (público o privado).
  • ejecutar en la carpeta de donde esta vpenadocs
  • C:\Users\neme_\vpena-docs> mkdocs gh-deploy
  • Para forzar el deploy: mkdocs gh-deploy --force
  • ir a mi ghpages: https://vpenat81.github.io/vpenadocs/ link

docs.title: Opcional pero recomendable si no carga en github
docs.text:
1 Limpia tu sitio local - Windows powershell: rmdir /s /q site - Linux bash: rm -rf site

2 Reconstruye tu sitio - mkdocs build - mkdocs gh-deploy --force (le dice a MkDocs que reemplace lo que ya está en la rama gh-pages, incluso si no detecta cambios)
